description.text: gun 007 by Hugo Gabriel [created on 3DTin]

Modeled after a commercial one that I have that is degrading due to UV exposure. I gave it a bit more of a positive grip than the commercial one.  
I printed this in nylon and it works, although I wouldn't trust it to hold a sink full of water all day or anything. It will definitely serve my purposes for washing the occasional dishes and such. Printing with a more rubbery material would likely make it as good as the commercial one. If I print another one I may try scaling it in the Z axis to be a bit thinner and thus more flexible, as it's just a bit on the stiff side.

title: Zen Toolworks Cricut cutting blade mount

description.text:
This is a simple remix of B-Cup's lovely design. I simply loped off his mounting hardware and super-glued it onto a plastic brick. This setup works quite well for me. If everything is working correctly this mount should not see very much force applied to it. I use it to cut kapton film for solder-masking circuit boards I mill on my ZenToolworks CNC.

See B-Cup's original file for the parts list. Pro tip: spend a bit of money on decent bearings, I bought the cheapest ones I could find on Amazon and they are only barely functional for this purpose.

title: CR-10 Z-axis endcap for max printing heigh.

description.text:
A new endcap for the CR-10's Z-axis in order to fully utilize its heigh. Should get you up to 420 (tehe) millimeters or at least one additional centimeter. It comes with snap-fit for the ball bearing, which can be reused from the original cap.

Not that it might be of terribly much use without also taking measures to reduce vibration but you gotta start somewhere.

No

Infill:

25%+

Notes:

Printed in 0.16 using PLA on 25% infill worked just fine. You should be able to print it standing with the bearing slot at the top in order to avoid the need for supports.

A friendly warning: DO NOT tighten it down just yet. Drive the hotend all the way up to ensure that it can move freely, THEN tighten it down. If you don't do this your motor can jam and your axis might bend.

author: ivoilic

print_settings.Notes:: You want your infill to be in the right pattern, and high enough to properly print the smaller bottom piece of this

description.text: This is a geometric solid, that has an equal diameter, so when rolled between two flat surfaces (see video below) will act as a sphere, even though it is not. The shape is based on a Reuleaux triangle, which has a constant width in 2D. This model is the 3D version, allowing a constant width in 3D. Because of this constant width in 3D, it allows this solid to act like a sphere. This concept is very interesting because you wouldn't think anything except a sphere could roll in this way, but this mathematical property of Reuleaux triangles allows this weird looking shape to work just like a sphere. I have designed this in multiple parts to allow it to print properly, and so that once it is finished and assembled, will work well. The pins to connect the two large pieces (the holes for the pins are on the bottom of the two large pieces) will need to be sanded down a little bit so that you can get a really tight fit between the two large pieces. So a little modification is required, but it is easily done, and works very well together once everything is tight. I hope you like this model!!

title: GI Joe Dragonfly
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The GI Joe Dragonfly helicopter, another of my favorite childhood toys. As usual, the file is modeled at the size of the actual toy but is intended to be printed at 25%. If you print one larger or smaller it may have too much or too little detail.

Print the chassis, skids, and gun pod with the bottom side down with supports.
Print the chin turret upside down with supports.
Rotor blade is printed in the upright position; can be printed without supports.
The rockets are the most challenging part. Intended to be printed upside down with supports, then very careful cleaning around all the parts is required.

Much respect and gratitude to the men and women of our Armed Forces (past and present). Your sacrifice allows people like me to live in peace, freedom and make silly little toys like these. It's you people who are actually "the real American heroes" and I'm really, really proud of you.

This file is a free download. Please note that it is listed as “non-commercial”. Neither you nor I are allowed to buy or sell physical copies of this 3D model. You are allowed (and encouraged) to print copies for your own personal use. If you have been re-directed to this file from a source other than my site on thingiverse.com they have done so without my permission. Thank you for respecting the rights of the original copyright holder.

Happy gaming!

title: Molecules
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Say hello to my little friends, Molecules! As a student I really enjoyed building models of molecules. I was a strange kid. I've been thinking about them for a while and Molecules were born.

I dedicate this Thing to Muzz64. Thank you for all your great designs and inspiration. This is the first thing I've designed in quite a while.

I'm initially releasing 5 molecules and source code.
CO2 - Carbon Dioxide - Black
H2O - Water - Blue
N20 - Nitrous Oxide - Pink
NaCl - Salt - White
O2 - Oxygen - Clear

I think these would be great tools for teaching simple molecular science. Certain Molecules like Carbon Dioxide and Oxygen make great hand fidgets. I think the real fun in this project will be printing in the different colors.

title: Titan Aero BLTOUCH and Layer Fan whit x Carriage

description.text:
v2
x Carriage
Corrected some gaps
bigger hole for the cables ( now the stepper connector fits easily )
added reinforcement in the stepper holder

Layer Fan
corrected dimensions for the layer fan
added more room for the air intake
corrected the holes for the screws

V1.0

new support for the cables to exit to the back

added 1 mm free space for lower belt ( to user with 16 tooth )

corrected the layer fan position and added thickness , the holes are for m3 screws , no nut needed

use the large Titan Screws

use the wheel not the alem screw for the feed screw ( no room to adjust with the alem )

the offsets for the probe in Marlin are

define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 5 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]
define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 26 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]
define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -0.91 // Z offset: -below +above [the nozzle]

and im using this values in the Marlin ubl section :

define UBL_MESH_INSET 1 // Mesh inset margin on print area
define GRID_MAX_POINTS_X 15 // Don't use more than 15 points per axis, implementation limited.
define GRID_MAX_POINTS_Y GRID_MAX_POINTS_X
define UBL_PROBE_PT_1_X 5 // These set the probe locations for when UBL does a 3-Point leveling
define UBL_PROBE_PT_1_Y 274 // of the mesh.
define UBL_PROBE_PT_2_X 10
define UBL_PROBE_PT_2_Y 30
define UBL_PROBE_PT_3_X 195
define UBL_PROBE_PT_3_Y 26
define UBL_G26_MESH_VALIDATION // Enable G26 mesh validation
define UBL_MESH_EDIT_MOVES_Z // Sophisticated users prefer no movement of nozzle

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53778 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=53778

Using the following options: extruder_colour = Colour1
bracelet_diameter = 84
link_diameter = 25

The latch in my MK3 Supra broke in half, so I designed another one in OpenSCAD using the original part and my digital calipers.

The SCAD file needs some touching up (I've got hard coded numbers spread through-out) but it works, I recently added some support corners to the weak spot in the model.

So far this design has been working out for me. The original part has rounded corners, but I'm not sure how to design that in OpenSCAD.

You are welcome to ask me questions of the model, ways I can improve it, or make it better. I plan on designing a lot more MK3 Supra parts in the future.
I just ask you don't make money off of my designs.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2000

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I didn't take note of the settings I used for the printer, but you don't want the resolution too low, and you need to use a support the middle piece and under half of the part.
For that reason I recommend printing this part laying down as I have it in the file, side ways seems to have a lot of structure weakness.

title: ANET A8 60mm LED Ring Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I designed a LED-Ring-Holder for my ANET A8. It is mounted via the single screw which fixes the extruder to the extruder-slide thing (no idea how it is called).

It is for 60mm 12V LED-Rings like this one:
2x 60mm LED Ring 12V

I've designed two versions, one for a ring width of 5mm (i've printed a previous version of this one for me) and one with 8mm width.

If the ring does not fit in the holder, try to sand the three noses/hooks a bit.

title: Oktober Guard C.U.B. light tank (GI Joe)

description.text:
The C.U.B. (Close-quarters Urban Brawler) is a light scout tank used by the Oktober Guard, the Russian equivalent to the Joes. This vehicle was never an actual toy but I wanted them to have one more type of tank. I made it up though it's based on a tank called an MT-25. As usual, a full scale model intended to be printed at 25%.

Printing is straightforward; both parts right-side up with supports. It's a small model so cleanup shouldn't take too long.

Much respect and gratitude to the men and women of our Armed Forces (past and present). Your sacrifice allows people like me to live in peace, freedom and make silly little toys like these. It's actually you people who are "the real American heroes" and I'm really, really proud of you.

I created these files and they are free to download. Since I did not copy any existing IP I can set the permissions as I choose.
If you have been re-directed to this file from a source other than my site on thingiverse.com they have done so without my permission.

Happy Gaming

remixed_from.title: 1.9 and 1.55 RC Scale Truck Wheel with Hubcaps

description.text:
Combined several of my favorite designs and styles to make a 1/14 scale rim that fit the design I wanted for the OSSUM jeep modifications I'm doing. I have not made a beadlock out of it, so they will need to be glued, but the steel rim versions were separated in halves to make for easier printing, and be assembled with a few M2 (or m3) screws.

I can make several offsets for these rims easily. but I included 0 offset, and for the steel style a 2.5mm offset for the Jeep design I intended them for.

these are intended to be used with 1:14th scale Tamiya semi truck tires like can be found here:
(https://www.aliexpress.com/wholesale?catId=0&initiative_id=SB_20170526173438&SearchText=1%2F14+tamiya+tires)

6/1/17

  • m.2 nuts didn't QUITE fit comfortably in the steel rim back so I enlarged them slightly. along with the slit for the axle peg.

  • I have printed 4 rims, mounted 4 rims, and can confirm they fit snug with the tires. there was a small amount of prep (typical with home printed objects) to get the screws and nuts to fit but everything tightened down and lined up! I used M.2 screws, but m1.6 may look more accurate.

  • One other note is, although these lock together for easy printing, they are NOT true bead-locks, and the fit is snug enough to be driven around for my scale brushed truck but if you plan to run these on a higher power system I suggest gluing the tires to the rims.

title: 31mm Filament Spool Rod for HICTOP printers

description.text:
A rather simple 31mm diameter rod that's threaded for the bolt HICTOP uses as a filament spool holder. Most of my filament spools have a 32mm core, so this rod lets them spin more smoothly.

I'm happy to make other diameters if anyone wants one. If you don't have any spools with that small a core diameter, you might as well have a larger diameter rod. :-)

Also included is a threaded end cap for the HICTOP rod. It will screw onto either end of the rod.

Update: There is now a 5mm slice for test printing to check the bolt's fit. You can then tweak the scale and reprint as needed.

Printer:

HICTOP 3DP-17

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I would suggest a thin layer height so the threads print cleanly. As well, since the ends are somewhat rounded, I suggest using a skirt that touches the rod model to give it more support while printing.

I printed mine in PLA with two shells and a 10% honeycomb infill. It seems to be lasting quite well with no signs of wear.

For the end caps in the photo, I printed them at 0.05mm layer height just to give them a very smooth look.

title: 2 Way Orb Speaker
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I have always wanted to make a speaker in the shape of an orb or sphere. As I have never been really great at woodwork and I certainly do not have the equipment required to turn something like that out of a block of wood it never happened. Until... I got my 3D printer! I have been working on this design on and off and had a few attempts at printing the spheres. A few weeks ago I upgraded from my Cocoon Create 3D to a Cocoon Create 3D Touch (Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus) and with that I had another go. I scrapped all the designs I had made to date and started from a blank canvas and this design is the result. There is still room for improvement but I am quite happy with how it turned out.

Just so you know - this speaker is most definitely not designed for sound quality, it is the look that I was after. So don't expect this unit to produce ultra HiFi sound - but, it does sound good enough for me to use it and to have now gone started designing an "orb amplifier" to complement it

The "base" orb takes a standard 4" speaker (woofer). I purchased mine at Jaycar Electronics (Australia) but I am sure you can use anything you can get your hands on or you may already have laying around. The tweeter is an inexpensive 2" number I ordered from China (I could not find anything small enough and within my budget here readily available in Australia). I have not put any fancy filter in the unit (yet) all I have done is place a 6.8uF capacitor in with the tweeter to get the most simple cross over possible. Certainly room for improvement there but for now it does the job :)

I would very much like to hear what you all think of my orb speaker and if you decide to print your own then please share some photos etc!!

Update: I have just uploaded v2 of the stand and arm. These have a few small changes to make the arm fit more snug into the stand - this should help reduce the sagging of the tweeter orb

Update update: the orb amp - a simple amplifier to hook your iPod (or other device with a headphone jack) is now available as a separate download https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2348151

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 (see below)

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I was able to print everything without any supports and at almost full speed (6cm/s) using PLA. I used 2 fillament colours to contrast between the orbs and the base and arm that holds the tweeter orb up. Make sure you print the arm laying flat - the PLA should easily bridge at the top.

Print the speaker orbs with the hole for the speakers flat on the bed - without supports the orb should print fine

I use Cura to slice and found that it was better to do the tweeter orb at 0.1mm resolution - it just did not print well at 0.2

Even at higher speed the large orb took around 15 hours to print so you will have to be patient for this one - I think the total printing time for all components was around 25-30 hours. Also its important to make sure your print bed is level before printing the orbs so that the layers don't separate.

Wiring it up

You should be able to fit a wire for the tweeter through the arm - of course using a gauge that's not too large. The wire I am using is 4.5mm wide and 2.5mm thick.

I soldered the bipolar 6.8uF capacitor straight onto the positive terminal of the tweeter and soldered the cable on to the capcitor and the negative terminal. The woofer uses the same gauge wire and that slots nicely into the the space underneath the stand.

Woofer and tweeter wires are connected in parallel inside the back of the stand so that it can be connected to an amp.

description.text:
Update: I created a new mount that raises the camera 60mm higher. You can check it out here - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2457855

This is a quick and dirty Logitech C270 camera mount that I made for my Tevo Tarantula that is running on OctoPrint. I wanted something that allowed me to pose the camera, but was too lazy to design a ball/socket setup. I feel this will hold better in the long run anyway. It mounts on the left Z plate (original Tevo acrylic) and uses the two screws that hold the toothless pulleys. I was able to get it to fit with the existing screws. You also need a M4 x 10mm (or thereabouts) to assemble the camera bracket to the mount. An M3 x 16 or longer is needed to attach the camera to the bracket.

It may work with other models that have a similar camera housing. The hinge on this Logitech camera is 6mm wide and fits a 3mm pin (if that helps)

You will need to remove the existing clamp from the Logitech camera so that all you have left is the lens housing.

Once it's on, you can adjust the pan and tilt and tighten it down into place. You may also want to focus the camera (requires a little hacking). You can see how to do it here - https://tamarintech.com/article/ciclop_scanner_focus_fix

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2mm Layer Height

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Adjust layer height and infill to taste. The camera isn't that heavy, so it doesn't need to be super strong. And since I have it on the side of the Z rail that currently doesn't have a lead screw, I wanted it light weight.

If you have troubles with holes on vertical faces, you may want supports (that don't touch bed). Otherwise no supports are necessary.

Mounting

I just removed the two screws from the toothless pulleys on the acrylic and installed the camerabase.stl under those. It's not rocket science :D

Remove the screw that holds the camera housing to the existing clamp. You may have to dig out the two little stick on rubber plugs. Fit the printed clamp (cameraclamp.stl) in it's place and assemble to the mount.

The wire for the camera is running in the bottom channel of the Z extrusion and out to the right side where my Pi is (next to the MKS), and I used the handy plastic extrusion caps that came with the Tevo to hold it in place. Worked like a charm!

You may want to focus your camera once it's set - https://tamarintech.com/article/ciclop_scanner_focus_fix

OpenForge
=========
Dungeon edge corner tiles designed to be compatible with Dwarven Forge dungeon tiles.
The smooth set can be used for any number of things. Look at the Smooth floor tile set for ideas. There, I've done concrete, ice and dirt. Here I've done concrete.
These tiles are designed to line their walls up with walls from tiles butted up against their neighbours. These are designed to be used on the edge of the map or to give more usable space for the play area, particularly for 1x hallways which would be impossible to fit mins in unless the wall was moved. Because the wall now takes up some space, you will need to use edge buffers in some places to get the tiles to lay out properly.
Compatible tiles/walls in this series are tagged with OpenForge
You can find this set on github
OpenForge Sets
=============
  • Smooth Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc.
  • Smooth Edge Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc. Edge tiles.
  • Stone Tile Series - Stone tiles.
  • Stone Edge Tile Series - Stone edge tiles.
  • Crenelated Tile Series - Crenelated Tiles
  • Crenelated Edge Tile Series - Crenelated edge tiles
  • Tudor Tile Series - Tudor tiles.
  • Tudor Edge Tile Series - Tudor edge tiles.
  • Ruined Series - Ruined stone walls
  • Accessories - Pillars, etc.
  • Non-Series Tiles - Misc tiles, such as the pool
  • Module Specific Tiles - Tiles designed for specific modules.
    • OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our website, at our forums, or on twitter and facebook.
Printed in black.  Painted with successive layers of dry brush of grey, tope, and light grey.  Cracks are painted with wider lines of the light grey and a thinner line of black.

author: wingnut2k

description.text:
This is a case for a raspberry pi zero W with AdaFruit's excellent 4 Port USB Hub.

The first iteration turned out great, but I'm continuing to make changes. Stay tuned.

Intro Adafruit has an excellent USB hub for the raspberry pi zero W. However, I wasn't able to find any cases that seemed to fit both the pi and the USB hub. Here's my attempt to fix that. I really wanted to take my pi out into the big, wide world for some field testing, but it's been raining a bit over the past week. So I set out to design a case that could at least provide some protection against the elements. Look at all those USB ports! And in such a cute, compact package too. If only one could keep the rain off them. V 0.1 - Still updating a few dimensions... but it looks great! v0.2 It jiggles around a bit less inside the box now. Needs another iteration for the dimensions to be right on, but it's a good start.
Materials Needed A raspberry pi zero w 4 Port USB hub for raspberry pi 0 (https://www.adafruit.com/product/3298) 3D printer File

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/3JY6imId9Pg

Another "made up" GI Joe vehicle, the Iron Grenadiers H.I.V.E. (High-altitude Interdiction Vehicle, Experimental). As before, created to give the Iron Grenadiers faction some more vehicles to operate. A towed, mobile launcher for a Firebat airplane and the missile launcher from the Stinger for back up anti-air defense. As usual, a full scale model intended to be printed at 25%.

Two different versions of the trailer - a closed version and another with the Firebat and missile launcher deployed.

Printing is straightforward; both trailers printed right-side up with supports.
Wheels with the hubcaps up, no support.
Missile with the missiles pointed up with supports.

Much respect and gratitude to the men and women of our Armed Forces (past and present). Your sacrifice allows people like me to live in peace, freedom and make silly little toys like these. It's actually you people who are "the real American heroes" and I'm really, really proud of you.

I created these files and they are free to download. Since I did not copy any existing IP I can set the permissions as I choose. Print them, sell them, buy them, whatever. If you have been re-directed to this file from a source other than my site on thingiverse.com they have done so without my permission.

Happy Gaming

title: Printrbot Simple Metal Y-axis Cable Holder

description.text:
A modification of "Cable Chain" by ModelStation. My changes include eliminating one wall of the chain pieces so you can slide in the cables headed to your extruder stepper and hot end without detaching any wires. This set of wires always seem to droop into the build plate on the Printrbot Simples, this worked as a solution. I also added a chain end and a stepper motor mount. You'll need some 35mm M3 screws (a little bit longer than the stock stepper screws to allow for the space the mount takes up). I found some flathead M3x35mm at my local hardware store.

I left the wires in the sleeving that the PB Simple comes with but did cut it down a bit on either end, I then used small zip ties to secure the wire sleeving with the wires inside to the vertical pillars on every other chain link. It keeps your build plate clear and looks pretty cool.

I imported the meshes for original "Cable Chain" into Fusion 360, turned off history capture, performed a mesh to BRep, then in the patch workspace performed a merge. I had a few artifacts left over after this process, I was able to remedy them with a couple cuts. I then had a workable object in Fusion.

title: Wasp Trap (redesigned!)

description.text:
Easily turn your old soda and drink bottles into wasp traps, cap prints quickly and is reusable! if you print one i'd love to see how many you catch! If you would like to see my design process from start to finish please watch the youtube video https://youtu.be/EpzpM1o6i6k

REDESIGN NOTES!
after a few weeks of use i made some critical improvements. the size of the funnel has been increased as to allow large wasps to enter. the flower is now a wild rose style flower that should print with petal details. the flower is thicker so if the bottle is knocked over it wont shatter. also i incorporated a new cap design that takes less plastic and looks a lot sharper! enjoy!

Printed on a printrbot simple metal at .15mm resolution in PLA (1.75mm). Designed in 123d design and sliced in cura. fill with dishsoap (to break surface tension) and beer (which attracts wasps and not bees).

I used JBijnens soda cap model for threads found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:806488

title: SwitchGrip - Nintendo Switch Multi-Function Grip
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
SwitchGrip - Nintendo Switch Multi-Function Grip

Disclaimer

I am not responsible if you cause any damage to your Nintendo Switch or your joycons, this print requires an extensive amount of post processing in order for it to work best.

What is SwitchGrip?

Update: 7/14/2017:

  • Updated design so joycons are easier to remove and uses less filament

Update: 5/28/2017:

  • Updated pictures to reflect new model

Update: 5/27/2017:

  • Removed bottom fixture where the joycons rest in order to make it easier to remove them also removed joycon locks since it made it harder to remove joycons.
  • Updated lock so it matches new dimensions

I'll add updated pictures when it's done printing, current pictures are not using the latest stl files.

SwitchGrip is a multi-functional Nintendo Switch grip, it can be used with the switch or with the joycons allowing you to have a more comfortable grip no matter which mode you prefer to play your switch in.

SwitchGrip allows you to dock your switch with the grips with the OEM dock and with my dock replacement Docky: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2258301

What did you use to build this model?

I used Blender to make this 3D model.

Files for 3D Printing

  • switch-grip-left.stl (left grip)
  • switch-grip-right.stl (right grip)
  • switch-grip-lock.stl (locking mechanism to secure your switch)

How can I use this with my joycons?

You need to download my other 3D model Jolder: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2328017

Thanks

Special shout out to jgr526 the creator of the comfort handles which I used to create this remix, without his initial work this would not be possible.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Print with 4 outer shells for solid rails.

This print requires extensive post processing, the rails are super tight so they require a lot of sanding and constant inserting/removing of the joycons until they slide in and out with ease.

If your joycons get stuck don't panic get a screw driver or any metal tool with a rubber grip and use the rubber portion to push the joycon out of the 3D printed grip with caution not to break the 3D grip.

You will need a lot of patience and sanding until you get this working. I used a 100 grit sand paper and sanded both grips I also sanded the portion or the locks that go into the grips so the can be inserted with ease.

I hope you enjoy SwitchGrip if you have any feedback make sure to let me know via the comments.

Enjoy

description.text:
The blower fan that came with my Anet A8 never worked. I have a bunch of 80mm fans lying around so I designed this to use the guts of an 80mm fan. You will undoubtedly need to modify how your fan connects to the body. Be sure to balance your fan on its axle, otherwise your fan will be loud and inefficient. I have included a step file which will hopefully allow you to modify the design.

*I'm not sure how much the stock fan cooled, but the first time I used this I had my extruder set at 200 C and the fan set to come on after the first layer at 100% speed. When it did come on, it cooled the extruder down to 185 C and the extruder didn't have enough power to get it back to 200 C. I ended up setting the speed to 50% power. That made the extruder temperature drop by about 10 degrees, but the extruder was able to recoup.

Anet A8

minimum 5% if you can bridge, 20% otherwise

Notes:

You should not print the blades with supports, its already hard enough to balance without a bunch of supports stuck everywhere.

comments.text: "When it did come on, it cooled the extruder down to 185 C and the extruder didn't have enough power to get it back to 200 C" - It's because you need to blow not on the extruder, as implemented by you, but on the printing area. I also had a similar problem with a heating block and a regular fan, but with a double-sided blowing nozzle. The problem was solved by replacing the heater and the thermal sensor, as well as with the thermal insulation of the heating block (the latter is not necessary, but slightly improves the efficiency and protects the blowing nozzle from the heat). Now, with any air cooling, the temperature is not lower than the set temperature and oscillating within +1 degree above. This solved a lot of problems with extrusion. And problems with blowing are solved by installing a well-directed nozzle. I tried to use circular, and semicircular, but in the end, the best way is to handle bidirectional: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2088006
comments.author: Sadhaka

comments.text: Thanks for your reply. I actually did think that it was due to the new nozzle being aimed more so at the extruder. I have plans to angle the nozzle more so at the printed material than the extruder. Unfortunately, the nozzle and printed material are always in close proximity. That being said, dropping the fan speed has worked for the time being.
comments.author: Sadhaka

comments.text:
I also found out recently about such a thing as PID calibration. Look for information on this issue, watch the video. Calibrating a PID extruder with a fully-powered fan can be very helpful. It seems that it is possible to set the PID values through the printer's menu on the native firmware. I do this through the firmware of Arduino. Calibration of the table is carried out only through the firmware. The temperature is therefore stabilized.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dU2S1heu3XU

40 deg GoPro Session mount (NinjaFlex TPE), top plate (ABS), and angled shock resistant antenna mount (TPU). All these parts were designed to work together to make ur HMB-X5 more durable and serviceable.

The GoPro mount is 40deg and is secured to the top plate with M3 bolts and lock nuts on the underside. It's very secure, have yet to eject a GoPro using this solution after about 6 months, use a high quality strap to keep your GoPro on the mount.

The top plate is 2.5mm thick ABS, it includes the standard stand off holes, the custom holes that fit the GoPro mount, and convenient slots for mounting your control antennas using zip ties and heat shrink. Again, I have yet to break one, I've been using it for about 3 months.

The antenna mount is made from semi-flexible SainSmart TPU. I've soldered a straight SMA on an extra long cable to my VTX so that there is some slack. In the event of a crash, the mount flexes and the coax feed line is free to move inside the frame. Your VTX, your top plate, your antenna, and your SMA connector are all spared, the mount just bounces right back to its original position. I recommend stiffening up your antennas with some heat shrink.

author: justinmklam

print_settings.Notes:: I designed this to be printed with the Mobius camera hole facing down.

description.text:
This is a mount for the Turnigy Bonsai flying wing that mounts a Mobius Mini and Eachine TX02 FPV camera on the front of the wing.

There are two versions to download - the _tv version has simply been rotated to make it look better on Thingiverse, the other version is the original export from Fusion 360.

The center hole allows the Mobius to be mounted with the metal heat-sink/camera mount attached for cooling. It also helps stop the Mobius sliding out backwards, but with velcro this isn't necessary.

When printed in PLA as described below it weights around 8 grams. I've tried to remove as much extra plastic as possible and still have it fairly rigid.

The way I've mounted it means the Mobius can only see a very small amount of the tip of the wing, and the FPV camera can't see the wing at all. When mounted the angle is such that it faces straight ahead when in flight.

Mounting tips

The mount is attached to the Bonsai using 3mm cable ties. The two front cable ties holes are designed to sit above the foward slot in the plywood battery mount. The cable tie runs over the battery strap and back up.

The rear cable ties run through the foam, and the battery strap runs under these to allow the battery to be mounted slightly rearward to fix the center of gravity (see notes below).

The FPV Battery for the TX02 sits behind the COG before the motor. This helps offset the weight of the Mobius and FPV camera.

Center of Gravity

Using this mount and the Mobius will cause the Bonsai to be nose-heavy. I rectified this by moving the battery back by 10mm as shown. Your mileage may vary.

Notes

  • Pictures show a previous version that is heavier
  • I'm running 850mah, 3S flight batteries for around 8 min flight time
  • I'm using 750mah 1s FPV batteries for around 30 min FPV time
  • The combined weight of the TX02 and battery is around 31 grams, the combined weight of a TS5823 transmitter, aerial and camera (without mount) is around 40 grams, so this is surprisingly a lighter option, plus it doesn't use the flight battery.
  • range on the TX02 (200mW) is great, I can fly the Bonsai out of sight and still get good reception
  • I'm using a Mobius Mini B with 135 degree lens.
  • Cable tie holes have recessed channels for the ties to run through.

Tarantula

title: Simple change filament while printing
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bm212othHy8
I improved the script to replace the filament during printing at the specified height. In while printng printer. During printing, the printer stops at the preset height, lifts the nozzle and waits for a plastic replacement, when you press the button the printer will pull the feed from the extruder and wait for the button to load the filament. Now you do not have to manually pull the filament out of the extruder and suffer to push it in again, the printer will do everything in automatic mode. If you ave quastions please write me and i wil be happy to help you! :) Please whatch video and if you like it support me and subscribe to my channel, for me it is very important. Good luck and happy printing

description.text: DIY wheels made on the lazzzor and assembled to make cool and kickass wheels for your next robot.

Lazzzzor out these wheels in quarter-inch birch plywood. Stack them up 3 high and secure with a hub (Pololu P/N 1083; this is for a 6mm axle) using #4-40 x 1" screws. Use Loc-tite on the nuts to keep them from falling off! Finally, put a rubber band over the teeth of the wheel. I used a #105 rubber band, which is 5/8" wide x 5" long.

A simple reverse bowden holder.

The Nimble is a direct drive extruder and does not need a bowden tube, in fact it replaces the need for a bowden tube all together. But some people like to guide the filament to the Nimble using a kind of reverse bowden tube.
This holder will fit over the drive cable and the other end will hold the bowden tube over the breech opening of the Nimble. The same part can also be used at the stepper end. Separate clips are available to clip the reverse bowden tube to the drive cable along the complete length and hold the wires (for hot end and fans) as well.

The Nimble Extruder

With an installed weight of less than 27 grams on your carriage/effector the Zesty Nimble is smallest and lightest extruder you can buy, it has ample torque and can be mounted in multiple orientations.

The Nimble is available from Zesty Technology.

This is a remix of "D'k Tahg" by BiancaW, published Dec 21, 2016.

I split the parts for separate printing in either different colors or for painting. Print the handle parts with full support of your choosing (what works best for you) and 2 each of the wing blade and switch pieces. For the switch, I used a 3mm fiberglass rod. I would suggest splitting the blade in half on the Z axis to make it easier to print.

I will try to post a photo of my finished piece soon.

05/28 update - I have uploaded files for another handle/blade rework. They should fit better and I added screw holes for assembly.

05/29 pdate - Photos is the first rendition posted.

A Bottle Opener for my favorite football club FC SION. 13 Swiss Cup Finals, 13 victories. Just magic, legendary, a myth. Print it and insert a coin into the gap. You can use a piece of 10 Rappen (Swiss coin, hieght 1.42 mm, diameter about 19 mm). Other coins should also work, but I didn't try the EURO coins. You have to press the coin very strongly into the gap, until you hear a "clikc"-sound. The best way to insert the coin is with the help of a flat piece of metal.

title: BQ Hotend DIY
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Hotend of my BQ Hephestos Extruder is clogged or damaged. The extruder works fine. A new BQ hotend costs 40€. Way too much.

I ordered a heater block, heater cartridge, thermistor and nozzle on aliexpress.

The BQ Hotend is mounted in a 6mm hole and secured with a bolt.

I bought a 6mm pipe with 1mm thickness in the local hardware store (https://www.bauhaus.info/metallprofile-kunststoffprofile/kantoflex-rundrohr-/p/10526883).
I attached a M6 outer thread on the one side and a M5 inner thread on the other side. The hole for M5 is 4.2mm, so a 4mm ptfe tube fits nice and snuggly.

I used a DIN913 M5 threaded pin and cut it in half. The part with the hex secures the ptfe tube in place. The hex is 2,5mm, so the 1,75mm filament passes through easily.

Now I can use standard hotend parts on the BQ extruder (which in 2 years never had an issue). I know, it's no printed part, but I think it can help someone having such kind of extruder :-)

Update 25.06.2017
Today I printed the first part with my DIY hotend. Looks great, everything works fine.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d3_24Bz5s_Q
I also changed the BQ connectors to JST XH2.54 and MOLEX KK396 connectors. I attached a KK396 header to the original heater cartridge cable in order to use the original hotend again.

title: Anet A6/A8 Y Belt Holder Upgrade

description.text:
Assembling the Anet A6 3D printer kit, I found that the Y Belt mounting was way to high for consistent belt tension. The belts included with the kit are thicker than standard GT-2 belts and more inflexible - I decided to replace them with standard RepRap GT-2 belts (eBay).

The model is Prusa Style and comes in two flavors, one for the kit belt and one for the thin RepRap belt (Thin in name).

I replaced the screws with 2x M4 10mm and 2x M4 25mm.

To tighten the belt, lose the motor screws (or pulley), mount the belt loose, press the motor in place and gently re-tighten the motor screws.

>> Don't forget, if you like it, please leave a like or a tip... :)

Update November 12. 2017:
Added A6 version with extended base (+4mm) for printers with greater distance from belt to y-carriage (A6Ext in filname).

Update October 28. 2017:
Added slimmer version for Anet A8 - Postfix A8 in filename.

Update June 13. 2017:
Replaced with version (V2) with less height to give more room for the returning belt under the holder. Alignment is not perfect and belt loops are smaller to make room for the lower profile.

title: Hook-Up Wire Spool Vase
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I needed a neater method to store my electronics hookup wire. I buy hookup wire in short lengths and it easily gets tangled because it doesn't come on a spool.

I've begun experimenting with making objects that can be printed entirely in vase mode. This is my first serious attempt at something useful and was inspired by the Paracord Vase Spool.

If you're interested, the design file is available at Onshape.

Printed with PETG filament. I find PETG tends to ooze and does not retract well, so I'm trying to design my objects with the least amount of retraction. Vase mode requires no retraction and as a result the finish quality is much improved.

Printed in vase/spiral mode for an extrusion width of 0.48mm.

Printed with PETG for strength and flexibility.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A ring fan duct for the "E3D v6 Compact Extruder for i3 Rework" by Mak-a-face.

The original Duct ist very good for airflow, but due to the one sided cooling, corners stand up and overhangs, that are not to the right side, don't look good.

This design removes the problems above and gives nice and even airflow, thanks to the ring.

This part should be printed with ABS or any other high temperature material.
If you use PLA, you should cover the inside of the ring with Kapton Tape.
This design has a lot of bridges, a FAN is NEEDED!

"The Lords of the Beyond after being banished left behind a large strip of devastated land, with ghost towns, buildings, temples and a whole range of localities. Rumors that in these places existed treasures, weapons and a whole range of fantastic things, began to arrive in the ears of the people of our world.

Individuals in search of fame and fortune have decided to enter these cursed lands in search of these prizes. Organized in small groups, they enter these lands and there they face dangers. This is the premise of Scavengers, a skirmish game in the devastated lands, where you lead a group of adventurers in search of fame and fortune.

Extracted from Alabar Chronicle´s, a Scavenger Guide to Our World"

Introduction

Scavengers is a table top miniature war game for fighting skirmishes with fantasy/steampunk figures. Two players fight a small scale combat with five to ten miniatures on each side (a hero and your henchmen). The game is easy to learn and play, though there is enough depth that it will take time and experience to master.

The game was designed around three core premises.

a) You can download our 3D models or use any miniatures in their collection. Thus, the game is not specifically designed to any particular manufacturer or company. But if you like to help the game dev, please download our models! (They are free and paid...)

b) It is important that the miniatures on the table be the focus of the game. In the end, miniature gaming should be about miniatures (and fun!)

c) A large background - We´ll develop new units, histories and game scenarios. But we need your help, sending suggestions to improve the game!

I hope you like our game and have fun! Ahh, an important thing: this is the basic core rules, our idea is releasing other books to improve the game!

This is a human archer you need to print 3 for a stand. Our gaming site is coming with our core book, game lore and a lot of new things!

More from Toy & Game Accessories

These are brackets to hold a glass bed to the "MendelMax Laser Cut Y Axis" by kludgineer assembly. The current configuration has an aluminum plate with an underside 110v 14W heater. STL and Google SketchUp 8 file included.

Brackets are easy to install and mount up to the M5 hex socket cap screws.
The glass is from a broken flatbed scanner. Glass is 3.1mm thick. 
** Also note that I had to add in a thin washer between the glass and bracket to space properly.

Slapped this together for a work colleague. Scaled it x2 before printing.
This thing was made with Tinkercad.

Summary

A 3D printable Mendecino motor.

Parts

The parts (on top of the 3D printed parts) required are

12mm3mm neodymium magnet: 6 off
20mm4mm neodymium magnet: 2 off
0.14mm enamelled copper wire: ~ 46M
Solar cell (0.5V, 53mm*18mm): 4 off (solar cells up to 80mm long can be used)
Flat headed nail (~4mm): 1 off

Build and Test

  • Print out all the 3D printed parts (I used black PLA for this).
  • Push the two 20mm magnets into the base mag_holder part.
  • Push the above part into the base (see pictures). The two plastic pins should hold it in. They must be the same way round magnetically (N or S poles up).
  • Push two 12mm magnets into one base_mag_holder part and two into the other (two of these parts are required). Take care to insert the magnets the same way round magnetically (N or S poles in the same direction).
  • Push both the above base_mag_holder parts into the slots in the base part. These must be inserted into that the magnetic poles are the same way round.
    Insert the spindles into the armature (they only fit one way round as one end is slightly wider than the other). The spindles that fit into each end of the armature may need some persuasion . If so then place a piece of wood over the end of the spindle and tap with a hammer so as not to burr the end of the spindles.
  • Cut the nail to leave the flat top with about 5mm shaft.
  • Push the above into the end stop (as show on the pictures)
  • Cut the point of the nail (length ~ 8mm).
  • Push this point into the end spindle_cap_pin part.

  • Push both the caps onto the spindle ends.

    At this point the plastic parts are assembled. To check that the magnets are all the right way round Check that the armature suspends correctly over the base (pin up against the end stop).

  • Wind the coils into the armature (both coils wound in the same direction) with 100 turns of copper wire. 50 turns to one side of the spindle and 50 turns to the other. The coils should sit in the flat bottom channels that run along the side of the armature.
  • Connect (solder) a single coil to the +ve and -ve connections on one solar cell.
  • Use two short lengths of enamelled copper wire to connect from one solar cell to the other on the opposite side of the armature. Ensure that the +ve and -ve connections are reversed (+ve → -ve and -ve → +ve) on the second solar cell.
  • Repeat the above two steps for the other two solar panels.
  • Secure the solar panels (each pair on opposite sides of the armature) with tape (masking tape) or elastic bands.
  • Test the motor using a strong torch to ensure it spins when light is applied. If there are problems with the wiring or solar panels, now is the time to fix them.
  • Once working glue (I used Gorilla glue but any gap filling glue should be ok) the two solar cells to opposite side of the armature. Secure these with masking tape while the glue dries.

Update

The motor would spin quite fast in strong sunlight and the armature could jump off the base. If the base_mag_holder_3_magnet part is used at the end of the base furthest from the end stop then this will stop this occurring.

title: Mecanum wheel
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
[UPDATE 1: Sorry, I just realized, that I accidentally used 80034 ball bearings, not 624 ball bearings for this design. I'm already working on a updated, new, better, nicer and prettier design, using "real 624" ball bearings. I'll publish this new design on thingiverse shortly. For more information on this, see
http://pleasantsoftware.com/developer/3d/2010/04/22/the-power-of-reading/.] [UPDATE 2: The new design is now available: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2473 ] Ok, RustySpoon1121 beat me on this one ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2318 ), but since my design is different (only 8 rollers, centrally mounted) and already finished anyway, I publish it as an alternative approach. I use 624 80034 ball bearings to mount the 8 rollers on the center wheel. For more information on the project (and more detailed build instructions), please see my blog post at
http://pleasantsoftware.com/developer/3d/2010/04/18/the-power-of-vacuum/

For one Mecanum wheel, you need to print:
  • 1 center wheel (either a left "Felge-links.stl" or a right "Felge-rechts.stl")
  • 8 holder parts ("Lager.stl")
  • 16 half roller parts ("Rad.stl")
  • 8x M4x60mm bolts (alternatively, 8x M4 threaded rod, each 60mm long)
  • 8x M4 nuts (16x if you use threaded rods instead of bolts)
  • 32x M4 washers
  • 8x 624 80034 ball bearings
  • 1x M3 nut
  • 1x M3 bolt, e.g. 15mm or M3 set screw

comments.text: Is there a reason you abandoned the removable bearing holders? Was there a mechanical reason? Seems like this would print better than the new one, since there is a lack of good support material.
comments.author: Rift

comments.text: Assembling this design didn't work so good and the construction wasn't very sturdy. Printing the thing in one piece is much more stable, easier and more elegant.
comments.author: Rift

comments.text: Thanks for the reply =) I have actually printed several of the other variation (been meaning to post pictures). But the ABS ones still suffer from a bit of curling when its doing the delicate bearing holder parts. I have printed a few in PLA as well that did not have this problem. I'm pretty anal about how perfect my prints are and I find myself not just settling till its perfect.
comments.author: Zaggo

comments.text: Hi, I can get a 624 bearing, but can't figure out where you source 80034 from.  Can you please post a link?
comments.author: dmatsumoto

comments.text: Sorry, I can't remember where I got them. The number 80034 is written on the side, but I'm not sure if this is a general code or some manufacturer code... These bearings have an ID of 4mm, OD of 16mm and are 5mm thick.

comments.text: cool!  I will check it out -- thank you for the info.

title: Nanocar
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The model of thermally driven nanocar, that is a molecule built from C60 fullerene and is abour 3x2 nm size. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nanocar.

That molecule was synthesized in 2005 [1] and is an example of so-called molecular machines. The Nobel Prize in Chemistry 2016 was awarded jointly to Jean-Pierre Sauvage, Sir J. Fraser Stoddart and Bernard L. Feringa "for the design and synthesis of molecular machines".

[1] Directional Control in Thermally Driven Single-Molecule Nanocars
Yasuhiro Shirai, Andrew J. Osgood, Yuming Zhao, Kevin F. Kelly and, and James M. Tour,
Nano Letters 2005 5 (11), 2330-2334
DOI: 10.1021/nl051915k

The molecular model of nanocar was drawn in Avogadro, geometry was optimized with molecular mechanics. The model was then exported to Mercury, which was used for STL file generation.
Van der Waals radii are used as atom radii, alkyl groups are not drawn for simplification.

description.text: I was struggling to print other Med-X models vertically well, or horizontally with support, so I made this version where the pieces are split in two and printed horizontally. It worked great for me!

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Printing with supports on gives some body inside the hollow model for gluing up, so don't remove it when done!

I mixed up some 5min Epoxy and laid that down inside each half of the body model. I then applied super glue to the flush faces and glued the two pieces together. The Super glue tacked it together and the epoxy gave it some heft and strength.
I used the original models from Printprops and edited it within Fusion360 to make the split.

A glue on mod to move the z-axis homing adjustment to the front right of the printer.
Note that there was talk of reserving this area for a spool holder.
The switch is mounted on the regular ZEST part.
Version two uses splines to lock the screw so it can't rattle out of position.

3d printed and tested but slic3r (at 0.2mm) does strange things.
There are no errors reported by slic3r or netfabb but in my case it added a single fill layer to the hole and printed the back and side walls hollow.
The hole is small and intended to be tapped to M3. There is enough material to allow larger threads to be used.
I printed in PLA and superglued it to the existing ABS part. Version-2 is a bit more challenging. The pieces fitted together with minor filing and clean up but I don't know how well this will work when printed on another printer. When completed the large knob with internal spline locks the two 10 tooth splines together. To adjust you lift the knob off the lower spline and rotate. When in position lower the knob to lock again.

title: Ord Bot Hadron trapezoidal z holder.

description.text: I bought from ebay seller marchantdice trapezoidal leadscrews and nuts for my ord bot (8mm, 1.5mm pitch). Search in ebay for TR8x1.5Dx500mm. Here is my design of nut holders. Mounts at the same plase as old z holders with M4 screws and nuts. 2 parts of the holder mounts together with M3 screws and nuts.

There are 2 parts for z holder.
I printed it in PLA with 40% infill.
  • Print the parts
  • Additional adjustment may be required (like some scrapping with knife). It is mainly because of thicker bottom layer.
  • Put the nut inside and close the 2 parts.
  • Assembly 2 parts with 2 long M3 screws and nuts.
  • Mount it instead of old Z holder with M4 screws and nuts.
    All nuts have places for it.
    No support needed.

title: Orb Amp - Amplifier for the Orb Speaker
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is the (pretty basic but functional) amplifier unit for my Orb Speaker (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2347532). The design matches what I tried to accomplish in the Orb Speaker design and allows you to hook up your iPod (or another device with a headphone jack) and play your tunes at at a considerable level through the Orb Speaker. ** you can of course also use any other speaker that is capable of running up to 12 Watts

The design centers around the Kemo M032 amplifier module. This is a pretty general purpose mono amp that comes ready to use moulded in a plastic block. All you need to do is hook it's 5 wires up to the speaker, a power supply and an input and it is ready to rock. The Kemo unit should be pretty much available around the world (if not in a shop then use eBay). The great thing about it is that it is pretty much fool proof and runs on a wide variety of voltage and impedance without the need for any soldering. And even more important - i tested the unit for half a day and it hardly raised in temperature, which is a great thing when mounting it in a PLA print. Oh and, no need for the volume control suggested in the documentation of the Kemo module - just set the volume in the device you hook up to the Orb Amp

In my version I have used a stereo 3mm jack. I have soldered 2 1kOhm resistors to each of the stereo input channels and then ran those together to the mono input. I have designed the orb amp so the module easily fits in the "box". I have used a 3.5mm stereo jack for the sound input, a 3.5mm mono jack to allow for a 12 volt power input and an RCA jack for the output. For the rest all you need is a few screws, a few plugs and a bit of wire to make it all work!

Wanhao

Just solder a few connectors, resistors and wires. Use M3 nuts and bolts (32mm) to lock the amp unit in place

Also i opted for lower case as the caps makes it sound as if the word "like" is a command or being shouted rather than used casually... maybe a little to casually :)

i did two versions as the debossed text version will be a less fiddly to print.

author: Verstraete

print_settings.Notes:: Support is necessary for cable organizer only

title: Pixfalcon support with wires organizer and dampers

description.text:
After trying to find a Pixfalcon support without success, I decided to create one. A compact and thin design, very light for RC models where space isn't luxury...

Optimized for feiyu tech dampers of mini 3d. Cables (wires) organizer piece is one I made for a eagle tree microvector but is compatible with pixfalcon even if not perfect: that depend of your pixfalcon config.

After design and printed many prototypes, I finally stopped on iteration number 18.
Simply glue cable holder underneath pixfalcon support at 45 degres (look at photo from microvector for illustration of how glue cable holder)

Hope this support could help some people...

I know this pixfalcon have got a mpu6000 not so sensitive to vibration but I decided to go with dampers unit for a personnal pleasure.

Probably I would had a basic support for damper soon. Don't hesistate to ask if need.

Important notice: dampers must not be close for max efficiency so avoid to glue them without hole for air inside.

For illustration, you could have a look here on my other design on how wires goes on : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2348124

description.text:
I wanted a turntable to help with various spraying that you sometimes need to do (paint, filler, primer, etc.) and designed this in Fusion360.

This prints in 2 parts and requires a standard 608 skate bearing (that you probably have laying around from all those fidget spinners) that is press-fit into the underside of the top portion. It's designed to be a tight fit.

The top is the larger of the two pieces at 200mm diameter. The bottom is 150mm diameter.

Just make sure your parts don't experience significant shrinking, as this will make fitting the bearing difficult.
